sentences.text: Parliamentary elections were held in Madagascar on 29 May 2024 to elect the 163 members of the National Assembly (Madagascar)|National Assembly. The election took place a few months after Andry Rajoelina was re-elected in the 2023 Malagasy presidential election| November 2023 presidential elections, which were marked by low turnout and an opposition boycott.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-16 |title=Présidentielle à Madagascar: les premières estimations confirment la faible participation |url=https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20231116-pr%C3%A9sidentielle-%C3%A0-madagascar-les-premi%C3%A8res-estimations-confirment-la-faible-participation |access-date=2024-04-01 |website=RFI |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: The 163 members of the National Assembly are elected via a parallel voting system: 77 seats are elected in single-member constituencies by first-past-the-post voting, while the remaining 86 seats are elected in 43 multi-member constituencies (of two seats each) by closed list proportional representation using the highest averages method.

references.text: <ref name=":0">{{cite web|date=March 13, 2024|title=Tatitry ny Filankevitry ny minisitry 13 Martsa 2024|url=https://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites/conseil-des-ministres/2107-tatitry-ny-filan-kevitry-ny-minisitra-alarobia-faha-13-marsa-2024-lapam-panjakana-iavoloha.html|website=Fiadidiana ny Repoblikan'ny Madagasikara}}</ref>

sentences.text: For this election, 12 million people are eligible to vote. More than 450 candidates contested the election.<ref name="anadolu"/>

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=29 May 2024 |title=Madagascar holds key parliamentary election |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/05/29/madagascar-holds-key-parliamentary-election/ |access-date=30 May 2024 |website=Africanews |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Issues in the campaign included corruption, infrastructure and the economy.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=2024-05-29 |title=A Madagascar, l'opposition dénonce des élections législatives contrôlées par le pouvoir |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2024/05/29/a-madagascar-l-opposition-denonce-des-elections-legislatives-controlees-par-le-pouvoir_6236102_3212.html |access-date=2024-05-30 |work=Le Monde.fr |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: Voting was held from 06:00 to 17:00 on 29 May. Observers from the African Union and the Southern African Development Community monitored the proceedings. The election was overseen by the Independent National Electoral Commission (CENI). There was increased security. On 1 June, the Safidy Observatory, the country's largest election monitoring group, raised doubts on the neutrality, impartiality and independence of CENI in its conduct of the vote. The release of the provisional results by CENI was initially scheduled to take place on 8 June, but was postponed to 11 June.

references.text: <ref name="anadolu">{{Cite web |date=29 May 2024 |title=Madagascar votes in legislative elections |url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/madagascar-votes-in-legislative-elections/3234448 |access-date=30 May 2024 |website=Anadolu Ajansi |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Madagascar holds parliamentary elections amidst high stakes, international monitoring |url=https://menafn.com/1108274872/Madagascar-holds-parliamentary-elections-amidst-high-stakes-international-monitoring |access-date=2024-05-30 |website=menafn.com |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Madagascar: Increased security, protests likely nationwide through early June amid release of parliamentary election results /update 1 |url=https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2024/05/madagascar-increased-security-protests-likely-nationwide-through-early-june-amid-release-of-parliamentary-election-results-update-1 |access-date=2024-05-30 |website=Crisis24 |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Législatives à Madagascar: l'Observatoire Safidy évoque un «scrutin entaché d'incidents inquiétants» |url=https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20240601-l%C3%A9gislatives-%C3%A0-madagascar-l-observatoire-safidy-%C3%A9voque-un-scrutin-entach%C3%A9-d-incidents-inqui%C3%A9tants |access-date=2024-06-02 |website=RFI |date=June 2024 |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Afrique Législatives à Madagascar: la publication des résultats provisoires reportée à mardi |url=https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20240609-l%C3%A9gislatives-%C3%A0-madagascar-la-publication-des-r%C3%A9sultats-provisoires-report%C3%A9e-%C3%A0-mardi |access-date=2024-06-09 |website=RFI |date=2024-06-09 |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 11 June, CENI published the provisional results showing no clear majority. The pro-regime coalition IRMAR (Isika Rehetra Miaraka amin'ny Andry Rajoelina, All together with Andry Rajoelina) lost its majority and won 80 seats, while independents and the opposition party {{ill|Firaisankina|fr}} won 55 and 22 seats respectively. Other small parties such as FIVOI received four seats while the Kolektifan'ny Malagasy and Antoko Maitso hasin'i Madagasikara received one seat each. Turnout was estimated at 47%. Results from 122 polling stations were not included because fires destroyed voting materials on 31 May.

references.text: <ref name="africaresults">{{Cite web |title=Madagascar ruling party loses parliament majority |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/06/12/madagascar-ruling-party-loses-parliament-majority/ |access-date=13 June 2024 |website=Africanews |date=12 June 2024 |language=en}}</ref>
